attributes.title: Strategy Manajemen Internasional
attributes.description: Buku ini membahas bagaimana suatu perusahaan dalam melakukan internasionalisasi. pada era globalisasi dewasa ini, perusahaan tidak hanya dapat mengandalkan pasar domestik untuk menghadapi persaingan bisnis yang semakin ketat, tetapi juga dituntut untuk mampu melakukan internasionalisasi. oleh karena itu perusahaan perlu memahami strategi untuk go internasional. attributes.title: MENINGKATKAN KINERJA UKM PERSPEKTIF INTELECTUAL CAPITAL DAN PENERAPAN STRATEGY BISNIS
attributes.description: Salah satu usaha yang termasuk di dalam jenis usaha yang mengalami penurunan adalah usaha kerajinan “Krawang” (Karawo = bahasa Gorontalo) yang pada tahun 2006 telah di patenkan oleh pemerintah Provinsi Gorontalo sebagai produk budaya unggulan daerah yang menjadi identitas dan juga warisan budaya turun-temurun di Gorontalo. Karawang atau yang biasa disebut masyarakat lokal dengan karawo adalah berarti sulaman tangan. Karawo merupakan hasil ketekunan dan kerja keras pengrajin Karawo untuk menghasilkan selembar sulaman yang indah. Proses menyulam Karawo sendiri biasa disebut dengan istilah makarawo. Seni makarawo konon telah diturunkan dari generasi ke generasi sejak abad ke-17 dan tetap bertahan hingga hari ini

summary.value: Buku ini membahas tentang peningkatan UMKM dengan pendekatan Intellektual Capital dan penerapan Strategy Bisnis. Buku ini bertujuan untuk memberikan gambaran dan pemahaman kepada pembaca terkait peningkatan kinerja UMKM, dengan studi kasus pada UMKM Karawo di Provinsi Gorontalo. Buku ini menjelaskan latar belakang dan fenomena yang terjadi pada pengelolaan UMKM di indonesia. penjelasan terkait UMKM, Intellectual Capital, Strategy Bisnis, dan Pengukuran Kinerja UMKM dan terakhir hasil analisis peningkatan Kinerja UMKM.

attributes.title: Does order matter? Harmonic priming effects for unscrambled chord sequences
attributes.description: This study examines whether scrambling the order of chords in a tonal harmonic progression inhibits the speed and accuracy of processing in two behavioral harmonic priming experiments. Sixteen 9-chord sequences were selected from Bach’s chorales that either remain unchanged (thereby reflecting low temporal incoherence), or were scrambled to produce increasingly incoherent sequences (i.e., medium or high). To produce the scrambled conditions, a variable-order n-gram model (Pearce, 2005) was trained on a corpus of Roman numeral annotations from 100 Bach chorales (Verbeten & Sears, 2019). It then identified the scrambled versions (scrambling chords 2-8) that produced either medium or high estimates of model uncertainty. Sixty participants (30 musicians) indicated as quickly as possible whether the target chord was in or out of tune. In Experiment 1, the target chord was tuned 40 cents sharp relative to the preceding context. In Experiment 2, the optimal level of 'out-of-tuneness' for each participant was selected using an adaptive staircasing procedure in the training phase to ensure task difficulty remained constant across participants.

q1.value: Does order matter? Harmonic priming effects for (un)scrambled chord sequences: Experiment 1

q3.value: This study examines whether scrambling the order of chords in a tonal harmonic progression inhibits the speed and accuracy of processing in two behavioral harmonic priming experiments. In Experiment 1, sixteen 9-chord sequences were selected from Bach’s chorales that either remain unchanged (thereby reflecting low temporal incoherence), or were scrambled to produce increasingly incoherent sequences (i.e., medium or high). To produce the scrambled conditions, a variable-order n-gram model (Pearce, 2005) was trained on a corpus of Roman numeral annotations from 100 Bach chorales (Verbeten & Sears, 2019). It then identified the scrambled versions (scrambling chords 2-8) that produced either medium or high estimates of model uncertainty. Sixty participants (30 musicians) indicated as quickly as possible whether the target chord was in or out of tune. For trials in the out-of-tune condition, the target chord was tuned 40 cents sharp relative to the preceding context.

q4.value: First, scrambling the order of chords will affect the speed of processing. Specifically, unscrambled sequences (low temporal incoherence) will elicit faster responses compared to scrambled sequences (medium and high temporal incoherence) (H1). Second, musicians will be faster in their responses than nonmusicians (H2). Musicians will also be more sensitive to the task (measured with d-prime)  than nonmusicians (H3).

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: This experiment adopts a mixed design with fixed factors of temporal incoherence (within-subject: low, medium, high), modality (within-subject: major, minor), and musical training (between-subjects: musician, nonmusician). Random factors include participant and musical stimulus (crossed).

q9.value: The experimental session will be divided into two phases. In the first training phase, participants are presented with a randomized set of 20 additional stimuli from the low temporal incoherence condition, with 10 stimuli featuring in-tune target chords and 10 stimuli featuring out-of-tune target chords (foils). In the second experimental phase, participants will be presented with a randomized set of 96 trials (16 stims (8 in major and 8 in minor) x 3 incoherence levels x 2 intonation levels) in the main experimental session. The 96 trials were randomized such that the in-tune and out-of-tune conditions of each stimulus were not presented within 5 trials of one another.

q10.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

q11.value: Data collection for Experiment 1 has just been completed for 60 participants (30 musicians). Data analysis to examine the a priori hypotheses has not begun. The language model architectures, training corpora, stimulus sets, and anonymized experimental results have been stored on a secure, password-protected server that is only available to the contributors on the project. The data were collected and stored by a research assistant who is not directly affiliated with the project (i.e., as a co-author).

question.value: Participants were 60 adult members of the Lubbock community recruited through the School of Music and the Texas Tech University classified ads (TechAnnounce). Thirty participants with musical training equivalent or superior to second-year-university level form the musician group, and 30 participants with less than 1 year of musical training comprise the nonmusician group. All participants will provide informed consent, and the study was certified for ethical compliance by the Texas Tech Institutional Review Board. Participants will be excluded from the study if they are not US citizens or permanent residents, or if they do not report normal hearing, which will be confirmed with a standard audiogram administered before the experiment.

q13.value: Participants were 60 adult members (30 musicians) from the Lubbock community (at least 18 years of age).

q14.value:
Unfortunately, it is not possible to conduct a power analysis for the linear mixed-effects models (LMMs) in Experiments 1 and 2 because we do not have a priori estimates for the random effects (participants and stimuli) in the power simulations. Thus, we conducted power simulations for a 3×2×2 RM-ANOVA with the power level set to .80, and with a large effect size of partial eta-squared = .14 for the within-subject and between-subject fixed factors. 

The power analysis indicated that participant pools of 24 and 54 participants would be necessary to detect main effects of the within-subject and between-subject factors, respectively, and a participant pool of 20 participants to detect a within-between interaction. We therefore selected a participant pool of 60 participants.

question.value: Independent variables include temporal incoherence (WS: low, medium, high), mode (WS: major, minor), and musical training (BS: musician, nonmusician).

Dependent variables include logRT (i.e., log response time), d-prime, and Bias c.

Random effects include participant and stimulus (crossed) in a maximal random effects structure (i.e., intercepts and slopes for both random effects).

Discrimination performance on the intonation task will be estimated using sensitivity (d’)
and bias (c) measures from signal detection theory. We will follow the guidelines described by Kingdom & Prins (2016).

Dependent variables (logRT, d-prime, bias c) will be analyzed with linear mixed effects models using a full random effects structure as specified by the design of the experiment. Specifically, the models will include crossed random effects for participants and stimuli, with intercepts for each participant and by-participant slopes for the within-subject fixed effects, and with intercepts for each stimulus and by-stimulus slopes for the between-subjects fixed effect.

q20.value: Response times will be log-transformed to ensure normality of the residuals in the LMMs in both experiments. Visualizations will feature estimated means and standard errors for the back-transformed RTs.

q21.value:
Omnibus tests will consist of Type III Wald F tests with Kenward-Roger approximation for the denominator degrees of freedom with p<.05 criteria for the WS and BS factors and interactions.

To examine more specific hypotheses about the potential differences between the levels of each fixed effect, we will include a planned comparison corrected with Bonferroni adjustment to examine the predicted linear trend for temporal incoherence (low < medium < high). We may also include a contrast for low vs. high.

q22.value: Because RT data typically feature long-tailed distributions that violate assumptions of normality and homogeneity of variance in repeated-measures designs, Ratcliff (1993) recommends eliminating the top 5% of the RTs in the long tail (i.e., the slowest, outlier responses across participants and experimental conditions). If necessary, we will follow this recommendation.

q24.value: We will conduct a mixed effects stepwise regression analysis to predict logRTs from both groups (musicians, nonmusicians) using predictors related to the information content (surprisal) and Shannon entropy (uncertainty) of the target chord, as well as the number of chords between the target chord and the penultimate chord (V7) from the unscrambled (low temporal incoherence) condition. The information-theoretic predictors will be estimated by the probabilistic model that was used to select the scrambled versions of each stimulus for the medium and high temporal incoherence conditions.

attributes.title: A Mixed-Methods Examination of Culture and Meaning-Making in a Sample of Student-Veterans

q1.value: A Mixed-Methods Examination of Culture and Meaning-Making in a Sample of Student-Veterans

q3.value: Though there is strong evidence to suggest that student-Veterans face a number of important challenges as they transition out of the military and into college, there is a substantial dearth of literature examining these challenges with sufficient rigor and depth. One of the most important challenges is creating or finding new meaning-in-life as a civilian. This rigorous mixed-methods study will seek to better understand the lived experiences of meaning-making in a sample of student Veterans via both qualitative and quantitative means. This study will also explore the effects of culture, social support (from friends, family, and significant others), and symptoms of trauma on self-reported meaning-making processes as our student-Veterans seek meaning in their post-military lives.

q4.value: This study will be using grounded theory, so a priori hypotheses can actually inhibit the objectivity of the open-coding process (due to biases stemming from hypotheses).

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
While there have been some quantitative studies examining the presence and search for meaning-in-life in Veterans, after a relatively extensive review of the literature, there appears to be a significant dearth in literature that seeks to understand the lived experiences (i.e., qualea) of meaning making, in student-Veterans transitioning out of the military and into college. This study's design, while not expressly mixed-methods, incorporates a combination of quantiative and qualitative methods, though it is primarily going to use a phenomenological, grounded theory design to explore the lived experiences of our sample population. 
For the phenomenological, grounded theory, qualitative component, a semi-structured interviewing protocol was developed via a comprehensive process. The researchers wanted to develop a suitable means of collecting our data that both evoked rich description of their lived experiences of meaning-making during the Student Veteran's transitions into college, as well as, minimized the influence of the interviewers. Thus, the research team used the extant literature to develop an initial set of questions that was checked for factors that might unduly influence the interviewees (e.g., non-directionality of questions, clear protocols regarding probing questions communicated to the research team, how to answer questions about the study without giving any hints as to the research team’s hypotheses, and standardized training of research assistants used as interviewers). Then, the research team sent the interview to an objective expert outside of the university who is familiar with both the praxes of qualitative inquiry and the literature on Veterans’ mental health – Duane France, LPCC, - a nationally award winning licensed cliniican that works with Veterans (Duane is also a five time combat Veteran while also attending school part-time as a student-Veteran –  for additional feedback that was then implemented by the research team. The researcher team then piloted the interview with a real student-Veteran (SV) that is familiar with the Primary Investigator (and that will not be used in the final research study). The interview was checked for time and then processed with the volunteer SV for feedback on content, directionality of the questions, safety versus invasiveness, quality of interview location/environment (e.g., convenience for participants), and for feedback on whether any questions should be added. 
Student-Veterans will first be asked to complete a brief survey either at home prior to the interview or using the Warrior-Wellness Lab's equipment (i.e., a research iPad). This survey contains the informed consent, some screening questions to re-ensure participants meet the inclusion-exclusion criterion, a demographics questionnaire, Steger and colleague's (2006) Meaning-in-Life questionnaire and Zimet's (XXXX) Multidimensional Scale of Perceived Social Support to assess variance in the sample population on two subscales of meaning-making within the sample population (i.e., the search for and presence of meaning) and perceptions of social support. This is critical so that the research team can attempt to speak to whether the sample population already appears to perceive a sense of meaning in life on average or whether they appear to be actively seeking it out, and whether they feel connected to others (i.e., linked in the extant scholarship as being predictive of transitional stress) – factors that assuredly might affect the kinds of responses they provide to questions around their lived experiences of meaning-making while transitioning from the military and into college. Further, descriptive statistics will be calculated regarding the demographics of the sample population used in the study (i.e., via the demographics survey) for sampling and reporting purposes.
Most data for this study that will be used for analyis will be transcribed semi-sturctured interviews meticulously conducted by student research assistants of the Warrior Wellness Lab (as opposed to by the pimary investigator, which might introduce bias during the interviewing process). As such, the research team plans to implement nine credibility checks during the data gathering and analyses (i.e., open-coding) of recorded interviews recommended by Butterfield et al. (2009) to enhance the trustworthiness of our qualitative research outcomes - especially as it will be using a grounded-theory research design. A first safeguard noted by Butterfield and colleagues (2009) is usage of audio (and video) recorded interviews which will be used with all participants. This data will be securely locked away in a locked cabinet inside a locked office belonging to the PI and will use two audio-recorders and a Go-Pro attached to a tripod for each interview, all provided to the Warrior Wellness Lab by the psych department with the PI’s start-up funds. For interview fidelity, the PI has developed a standardized plan to train the research team on using the extensively-developed semi-structured interviewing protocol discussed earlier. In addition to all of the interviewers using the same interview, their training will include: asking non-directional questions, clear protocols regarding probing questions communicated to the research team, how to answer questions about the study without giving any hints as to the research team’s hypotheses, and standardized training of research assistants used as interviewers. We also plan to have a student that did not do any interviewing but that underwent the standardized training to audit every 4th interview to provide feedback to the interviewers about whether they were faithful to the protocol presented in the training provided by the PI. For another safeguard, during the coding process, one research assistant will extract one quarter of the transcribed interviews. Then, the PI will compare the independently extracted items with those extracted by the PI earlier in the process and will strive to come to a consensus where they appear to diverge. Any codes where consensus cannot be achieved will be discounted from the study. 
Further, initial coding by the PI will continue until it appears that no other codes emerge (i.e., exhaustiveness). Categories will need a 25% participation rate to be considered viable (Borden & Amundson, 1984; Butterfield et al., 2009). In other words, for a category to be considered viable, it will need to have been “endorsed” by at least one quarter of the study’s participants, per Butterfield et al. (2009). Code category placement will be assessed by an independent judge, wherein, one quarter of the total codes created by the PI will be randomly selected. A research assistant will then try to place them in the appropriate categories chosen initially by the PI. The independent research assistant must match the PI’s categories 80 percent of the time for the category to be deemed sufficient. Categories with less than an 80 percent congruence will be handled by seeking consensus with the research assistant and using follow-up interviews with participants during cross-checks to determine whether to keep a category. Cross-checking by participants in post will also occur. Participants that agreed to be contacted for a follow-up interview will be asked to participate provide some written responses to a series of interview questions, post data-gathering. The electronic follow-up interview will be used to appraise the degree of participant-consensus on the identified codes and categories, whether they appear clear and accurately represent what they intended to communicate, and whether any codes should fall under a different category (Butterfield et al., 2009). The research team can also use this as an opportunity to receive and answer questions participants may have about their participation in the research study. 
Affirmation of cateogories will be sought by expert opinion. Similar to Butterfield and colleagues’ (2009) use of expert confirmation, our research team will use an objective expert again - Duane France, LPCC, NCC – a national award-winning expert in clinical work with Veterans and student-Veterans – as a means of determining whether the categories that emerge during the coding process appear to have utility in exploring the phenomenon in question (i.e., lived experiences of meaning-making in student-Veterans), whether any categories appear to be missing, and whether any categories seemed surprising. Last but not least, the research team will explore theoretical agreement using the extant scholarship. The research team plans to compare categories that emerge through the coding process with extant theory and literature and if any category does not appear to align with pre-existing theory or research, it will be considered a potential variable of interest for future studies (Butterfield et al. (2009).
  Given that this is exploratory qualitative research with little to no extant research or literature to found any hypotheses and not seeking to make broad generalizations to a wider population of student-Veterans, the qualitative grounded theory design described above is strongly appropriate for exploring the lived experiences (i.e., phenomenology) of meaning-making during the student-Veterans' transition to college.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will receive a $10 amazon e-gift card for completing one initial survey (demographics, perceptions of meaning-making, degree and quality of social support, symptoms of PTS) and a semi-structured interview conducted by an objective research assistant. They will also be entered in a raffle to receive a $30 amazon e-gift card to participate in the follow-up survey/interview examining whether they agree with any emergent findings from the coding process.

q13.value: Until exhaustiveness in the coding process is achieved (likely around 40 participants)

q14.value: Until exhaustiveness in the coding process is achieved (a credibility check built into our design to ensure we capture as much of the existing variance as possible).

q15.value: Until exhaustiveness in the coding process is achieved

question.value: N/A

-Life Satisfaction Questionnaire (Diener et al., 1985)
-Symptoms of Post-Traumatic Stress (PCL-5; See: Weathers et. al, 2013)
- Meaning-making and culture (semi-structured interview)

N/A

Quantitative data from the surveys will be analyzed via descriptive statistics. As the sample size for this study is small, inferential statistics (namely, correlation and multiple regression)  will only be used if there is sufficient statistical power.

registration_responses.q1: A Mixed-Methods Examination of Culture and Meaning-Making in a Sample of Student-Veterans
registration_responses.q3: Though there is strong evidence to suggest that student-Veterans face a number of important challenges as they transition out of the military and into college, there is a substantial dearth of literature examining these challenges with sufficient rigor and depth. One of the most important challenges is creating or finding new meaning-in-life as a civilian. This rigorous mixed-methods study will seek to better understand the lived experiences of meaning-making in a sample of student Veterans via both qualitative and quantitative means. This study will also explore the effects of culture, social support (from friends, family, and significant others), and symptoms of trauma on self-reported meaning-making processes as our student-Veterans seek meaning in their post-military lives.
registration_responses.q4: This study will be using grounded theory, so a priori hypotheses can actually inhibit the objectivity of the open-coding process (due to biases stemming from hypotheses).
registration_responses.q5: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.
q6: No blinding is involved in this study.

registration_responses.q8.question:
While there have been some quantitative studies examining the presence and search for meaning-in-life in Veterans, after a relatively extensive review of the literature, there appears to be a significant dearth in literature that seeks to understand the lived experiences (i.e., qualea) of meaning making, in student-Veterans transitioning out of the military and into college. This study's design, while not expressly mixed-methods, incorporates a combination of quantiative and qualitative methods, though it is primarily going to use a phenomenological, grounded theory design to explore the lived experiences of our sample population. 
For the phenomenological, grounded theory, qualitative component, a semi-structured interviewing protocol was developed via a comprehensive process. The researchers wanted to develop a suitable means of collecting our data that both evoked rich description of their lived experiences of meaning-making during the Student Veteran's transitions into college, as well as, minimized the influence of the interviewers. Thus, the research team used the extant literature to develop an initial set of questions that was checked for factors that might unduly influence the interviewees (e.g., non-directionality of questions, clear protocols regarding probing questions communicated to the research team, how to answer questions about the study without giving any hints as to the research team’s hypotheses, and standardized training of research assistants used as interviewers). Then, the research team sent the interview to an objective expert outside of the university who is familiar with both the praxes of qualitative inquiry and the literature on Veterans’ mental health – Duane France, LPCC, - a nationally award winning licensed cliniican that works with Veterans (Duane is also a five time combat Veteran while also attending school part-time as a student-Veteran –  for additional feedback that was then implemented by the research team. The researcher team then piloted the interview with a real student-Veteran (SV) that is familiar with the Primary Investigator (and that will not be used in the final research study). The interview was checked for time and then processed with the volunteer SV for feedback on content, directionality of the questions, safety versus invasiveness, quality of interview location/environment (e.g., convenience for participants), and for feedback on whether any questions should be added. 
Student-Veterans will first be asked to complete a brief survey either at home prior to the interview or using the Warrior-Wellness Lab's equipment (i.e., a research iPad). This survey contains the informed consent, some screening questions to re-ensure participants meet the inclusion-exclusion criterion, a demographics questionnaire, Steger and colleague's (2006) Meaning-in-Life questionnaire and Zimet's (XXXX) Multidimensional Scale of Perceived Social Support to assess variance in the sample population on two subscales of meaning-making within the sample population (i.e., the search for and presence of meaning) and perceptions of social support. This is critical so that the research team can attempt to speak to whether the sample population already appears to perceive a sense of meaning in life on average or whether they appear to be actively seeking it out, and whether they feel connected to others (i.e., linked in the extant scholarship as being predictive of transitional stress) – factors that assuredly might affect the kinds of responses they provide to questions around their lived experiences of meaning-making while transitioning from the military and into college. Further, descriptive statistics will be calculated regarding the demographics of the sample population used in the study (i.e., via the demographics survey) for sampling and reporting purposes.
Most data for this study that will be used for analyis will be transcribed semi-sturctured interviews meticulously conducted by student research assistants of the Warrior Wellness Lab (as opposed to by the pimary investigator, which might introduce bias during the interviewing process). As such, the research team plans to implement nine credibility checks during the data gathering and analyses (i.e., open-coding) of recorded interviews recommended by Butterfield et al. (2009) to enhance the trustworthiness of our qualitative research outcomes - especially as it will be using a grounded-theory research design. A first safeguard noted by Butterfield and colleagues (2009) is usage of audio (and video) recorded interviews which will be used with all participants. This data will be securely locked away in a locked cabinet inside a locked office belonging to the PI and will use two audio-recorders and a Go-Pro attached to a tripod for each interview, all provided to the Warrior Wellness Lab by the psych department with the PI’s start-up funds. For interview fidelity, the PI has developed a standardized plan to train the research team on using the extensively-developed semi-structured interviewing protocol discussed earlier. In addition to all of the interviewers using the same interview, their training will include: asking non-directional questions, clear protocols regarding probing questions communicated to the research team, how to answer questions about the study without giving any hints as to the research team’s hypotheses, and standardized training of research assistants used as interviewers. We also plan to have a student that did not do any interviewing but that underwent the standardized training to audit every 4th interview to provide feedback to the interviewers about whether they were faithful to the protocol presented in the training provided by the PI. For another safeguard, during the coding process, one research assistant will extract one quarter of the transcribed interviews. Then, the PI will compare the independently extracted items with those extracted by the PI earlier in the process and will strive to come to a consensus where they appear to diverge. Any codes where consensus cannot be achieved will be discounted from the study. 
Further, initial coding by the PI will continue until it appears that no other codes emerge (i.e., exhaustiveness). Categories will need a 25% participation rate to be considered viable (Borden & Amundson, 1984; Butterfield et al., 2009). In other words, for a category to be considered viable, it will need to have been “endorsed” by at least one quarter of the study’s participants, per Butterfield et al. (2009). Code category placement will be assessed by an independent judge, wherein, one quarter of the total codes created by the PI will be randomly selected. A research assistant will then try to place them in the appropriate categories chosen initially by the PI. The independent research assistant must match the PI’s categories 80 percent of the time for the category to be deemed sufficient. Categories with less than an 80 percent congruence will be handled by seeking consensus with the research assistant and using follow-up interviews with participants during cross-checks to determine whether to keep a category. Cross-checking by participants in post will also occur. Participants that agreed to be contacted for a follow-up interview will be asked to participate provide some written responses to a series of interview questions, post data-gathering. The electronic follow-up interview will be used to appraise the degree of participant-consensus on the identified codes and categories, whether they appear clear and accurately represent what they intended to communicate, and whether any codes should fall under a different category (Butterfield et al., 2009). The research team can also use this as an opportunity to receive and answer questions participants may have about their participation in the research study. 
Affirmation of cateogories will be sought by expert opinion. Similar to Butterfield and colleagues’ (2009) use of expert confirmation, our research team will use an objective expert again - Duane France, LPCC, NCC – a national award-winning expert in clinical work with Veterans and student-Veterans – as a means of determining whether the categories that emerge during the coding process appear to have utility in exploring the phenomenon in question (i.e., lived experiences of meaning-making in student-Veterans), whether any categories appear to be missing, and whether any categories seemed surprising. Last but not least, the research team will explore theoretical agreement using the extant scholarship. The research team plans to compare categories that emerge through the coding process with extant theory and literature and if any category does not appear to align with pre-existing theory or research, it will be considered a potential variable of interest for future studies (Butterfield et al. (2009).
  Given that this is exploratory qualitative research with little to no extant research or literature to found any hypotheses and not seeking to make broad generalizations to a wider population of student-Veterans, the qualitative grounded theory design described above is strongly appropriate for exploring the lived experiences (i.e., phenomenology) of meaning-making during the student-Veterans' transition to college.
registration_responses.q12.question: Participants will receive a $10 amazon e-gift card for completing one initial survey (demographics, perceptions of meaning-making, degree and quality of social support, symptoms of PTS) and a semi-structured interview conducted by an objective research assistant. They will also be entered in a raffle to receive a $30 amazon e-gift card to participate in the follow-up survey/interview examining whether they agree with any emergent findings from the coding process.

attributes.title: Genetic Association Study for PANDAS and PANS:  Phase 3
attributes.description: This 3rd phase of examination of genetic data from PANS/PANDAS patients determines additional SNPs (single-nucleotide polymorphisms) associated with these disorders.

data.value: It's complicated. We have already collected some data but explain in Question 8 why readers may consider this a valid pre-registration nevertheless.

name.value: Genetic Association Study for PANDAS and PANS: Phase 3

other.value:
Although almost all the data for this has been collected, because all SNPs reported in the data sets (with exclusions noted above) will be analyzed, there is no amount of peeking at the data that will allow any "hypothesizing after results known" or researcher degrees of freedom that could allow manipulation and an inappropriate declaration of significance for the results.  There is no limited SNP list (as was the case for the pilot and replication studies) that needs to be defined in order to choose a single multiple comparison correction factor in advance.  Instead, the criteria for significance will be p<2x10-8 (derived for whole genome with allele frequencies as small as 0.005 per https://www.nature.com/articles/ejhg2015269), or per the bonferonni correction for as many SNPs as are found to have minor frequencies < 0.005, whichever criteria is larger (as both are conservative).  For this process, i-numbered SNPs in 23andMe will be ignored unless a corresponding rs-ID was assigned as determined by chromosome and positions reported in data sets created later in time.  When an i-number or rs-ID are within 1 in position, they may be taken as the same SNP.

The “general population” data base will be constructed with all Databases available at dbSNP for each of the following 6 ethnicities: African, East Asian, Europe, South Asian, American, and Ashkenazi Jewish.  East Asian, South Asian and Europe are as defined at www.thefreedictionary.com.

Sample ethnicities will be determined at www.gedmatch.com with the "admixture heritage analysis" tool using the MDLP Project option, with "Admixture Proportions (With link to Oracle)" selected, and the MDLP World-22 calculator model.  For the purpose of calculating the representative “general population”, each sample ethnicity that registers greater than 10% will be mapped to the 6 dpSNP ethnicities as shown by example in Appendix A of the report titled PANDAS&PANS_Genetic_Association_Replication_Report at https://osf.io/wcbr9.

The dbSNP databases can be found at  https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/snp/rsXXXXXX#frequency_tab , where XXXXXX is the SNP rs#.

sample.value: 139 data sets have already been collected from willing participants or their guardians as a result of the pilot and replication studies reported upon here (https://osf.io/wcbr9).  Collection will continue until Feb. 1, 2020, 8am EST with the same consent form as was used for the replication study.

analyses.value:
Valid genetic data has been collected to date from 139 individuals with P/P (as diagnosed or parent-reported from symptoms) from 11 facebook groups and 1 internet forum (see the files section of the linked project for how existing data has been collected).   For each individual, counts of alleles for all SNPs listed in the data sets (minus exclusions per the next section) will be tallied and compared to the ethnically representative general population, in order to show genetic associations for the disorders of P/P.  The probability of obtaining the sample from the general population (under the null hypothesis) will be calculated as a binomial probability, reported for each SNP individually. A p-value will be reported as the result in this study. 

Because the survey group may include widely varying ethnicities, the “general population” reference allele frequency will be crafted to reflect the sample’s ethnicity, via allele proportions that are reported for each of several broad ethnicities.  See "Other" below for more information on how the general population data will be derived.

outliers.value:
Samples of data will be rejected if their independence is suspect (e.g. 3% or more relation to others in the sample, as computed at www.gedmatch.com using the "One-To-Many DNA Comparison Result" V2-A).  Of any such relatives, the oldest (if determinable) will be kept for analysis and the younger relatives will be excluded.  If relatives show among anonymous data, the oldest may not be determinable, in which case the file with the older date stamp will be kept, and the newer file excluded.  (Note that the above exclusion criteria have already been applied to the existing 139 data sets, they will be applied to additional data sets received until a Feb. 1, 2020 cutoff date).

SNPs with minor allele frequencies of less than 0.005 for the European ethnicity (as listed by 1000Genomes, or gnomAD Exome Data if the latter exists for the SNP) will be excluded from the analysis.  SNPs not reported in 1000Genomes GRCh37/hg19 as listed at https://www.snp-nexus.org/v4/ will not be examined.

SNPs with unusual results (p-values) may be outliers if there is an error in the data (i.e. incorrect SNP was called).  To confirm this, a p-value will also be calculated from 87 or more data sets retrieved from publicly available data at https://my.pgp-hms.org/public_genetic_data that are perceived to be largely of European ancestry (to match the P/P samples).  If the result is also unusual in public data (p<0.05 and within 4 orders of magnitude of the p result in P/P data, or having none of one or more of the 3 possible combinations of allele pairs, or reported/found as suspect by any reliable source), the SNP will be removed from consideration as a candidate for statistical significance.

dependent.value: Although the hypothesis is that certain genes are significant causal factors for P/P, the output variables from the data collected will be the allele and genotype counts for all SNPs called in the genetic data sets that have been collected, unless they meet exclusion criteria (defined below).

conditions.value: There will be no assigned conditions in this observational study.

hypothesis.value: What genetic SNPs correlate with PANS and PANDAS (hereafter both designated by P/P)?

attributes.title: The effect of probiotics used as a single therapy on functional constipation: a systematic review and meta-analysis
attributes.description: Are probiotics used as a single therapy more effective and safe in the treatment of functional constipation ?

summary.value: Are probiotics used as a single therapy more effective and safe in the treatment of functional constipation ? Chronic constipation is a functional gastrointestinal disorder characterised by persistently difficult, infrequent or incomplete defaecation that affects approximately 14 % of the general population. A variety of different management options exist on constipation. However, patient satisfaction is variable; for example, 49 % of patients initiating over-the-counter therapies and 58 % of patients initiating prescription therapies experience failure of that treatment. Another study reported that almost half of respondents were not completely satisfied with their current constipation treatment. The reasons for patient dissatisfaction were mainly related to efficacy and safety, as well as cost issues and inconsistent results. Taken together, these results show that there is still a substantial unmet need for new effective therapeutic strategies that would be appealing and satisfactory for people with constipation. Over the past decade there has been an increase in research investigating the effect of probiotics on chronic constipation as a potential alternative management strategy. However, there are still many differences in the efficacy and adverse reactions of probiotics improving symptoms of constipation in existing randomized controlled clinical studies. it is important to stress that RCTs that compare probiotics with placebo or TAU(treatment as usual)address a different question than RCTs that compare probiotics taken in combination with TAU to TAU alone (with or without placebo).

attributes.title: Investigating the genetic pathways of insomnia in Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD)

q1.value: Investigating the Genetic Pathways of Insomnia in Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD)

q2.value: Maria Niarchou, Beth Malow, Lea Davis

q3.value: Sleep problems, particularly insomnia, are common in individuals with ASD. The impact of sleep problems in individuals with ASD and their families is profound, affecting their quality of life and daytime behaviour. This project will be the one of the first studies to examine the genetic contribution of sleep and circadian disturbances in ASD and the first study to derive genetic risk profiling of insomnia in ASD, paving the way for precision medicine in sleep and ASD. We will use data from the phenotypically and genotypically rich MSSNG dataset and then run sensitivity analyses using the Vanderbilt University Biobank (BioVU). Gaining a better understanding of the potential involvement of the circadian and clock related genetic pathways to risk of insomnia in individuals with ASD, can help inform treatment in this population.

q4.value: We hypothesize that polygenic risk scores for insomnia and autism will be associated with insomnia in individuals with ASD. We also hypothesize that there will be a greater burden of rare and disruptive variation in the melatonin and circadian CLOCK genes in individuals with ASD and insomnia than individuals with ASD without insomnia,

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Two-group (individuals with ASD and sleep problems vs. individuals with ASD without sleep problems) case-control, cross-sectional study.

q10.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

question.value: Data is already collected. We will examine our questions by using data from the phenotypically and genotypically rich MSSNG dataset. We will also obtain additional phenotypic data from the AGRE dataset that maps into the genotypic data of AGRE that is included in MSSNG but has not yet been incorporated in the MSSNG dataset. A major strength of our project is that we will also incorporate analyses using the Vanderbilt University Biobank (BioVU). The BioVU sample repository consists of DNA and de-identified electronic health record (EHR) data.

q13.value: After working with the AGRE and MSSNG data managers, we have an estimate of the absolute minimum data on sleep problems that are available. From the AGRE dataset, there are data on the Children’s Sleep Habits Questionnaire (CSHQ)15 for 209 affected individuals, as well as detailed sleep data which is part of a medical history examination for 94 affected individuals, making a total of 303 affected individuals with extensive sleep data and Whole Genome Sequencing data in the MSSNG dataset. The MSSNG dataset also includes the Child Behavior Checklist (CBCL)16,17, that include questions on sleep for 810 affected individuals (independent from the individuals with data in AGRE). There are additional data that can be provided to us from the MSSNG dataset as several sites may have additional sleep data as part of their medical history assessments. In BioVU, we have also identified over 700 individuals with ASD who also have genotypic data as well as a wealth of phenotypic information on sleep and other medical comorbidities, including standardized surveys and clinical sleep histories. Taking into account that Vanderbilt University Medical Center has contributed to the MSSNG dataset, we will be careful to exclude any samples that overlap between the MSSNG and the BioVU samples.

question.value: See information in statistical models section.

Aim (1): We will generate two separate PRS predictors (i) insomnia PRS and (ii) ASD PRS to test for associations and interaction effects within a population of individuals with ASD who have insomnia (cases) and who do not have insomnia (controls). We will use GWAS summary statistics from the largest available independent GWAS of insomnia (n=113,006) and the largest ASD sample available at the time of conducting the analysis from the Psychiatric Genetics Consortium. Co-I Dr. Davis is a member of the PGC and thus has early access to PGC data. Briefly, for our analysis, risk scores will be calculated using the recently developed Bayesian polygenic prediction method (PRS_CS) that imposes continuous shrinkage priors on SNP effect sizes. We will derive scores in the MSSNG data from the average number of risk alleles per person weighted by the effect size (log-odds ratio) at each locus. Scores will be standardized, and regression methods used to obtain estimates of a unit-increase in each outcome per 1 SD in the score. At the time of analysis, we will review if methods that account for LD and use discovery data from multiple traits are more appropriate. We will combine the questions from CBCL, dichotomize them in a ‘yes/no insomnia’ variable to determine whether the presence of insomnia is associated with the insomnia PRS. We will then add ASD PRS to the model to examine its additional contribution to insomnia. We will then harmonise the CSHQ and the medical history questions from the AGRE dataset which are extensive and detailed. We will use the best insomnia PRS predictor identified from our analysis of MSSNG and examine its association with the CSHQ sleep subscales. We will replicate the analyses in the BioVU dataset. 
Aim (2): Using PrediXcan, we will generate predicted gene expression profiles for the individuals in MSSNG, AGRE and BioVU and identify genes for which predicted expression is associated with insomnia in affected as well as unaffected individuals. Our analyses using the independent datasets of MSSNG and the AGRE, will provide us with a benchmark upon which to more extensively examine insomnia in ASD including the role of medication and response to medication (see preliminary data section).  As an additional analysis and to take advantage of the rare variant data available in MSSNG, we will use the Sequence Kernel Association Test (SKAT) to examine whether there is a greater burden of rare and disruptive variation in the melatonin and circadian CLOCK genes in individuals with ASD and insomnia than in individuals with ASD and without insomnia.

registration_responses.q5: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.
q6: No blinding is involved in this study.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to accessing the data
registration_responses.q13: After working with the AGRE and MSSNG data managers, we have an estimate of the absolute minimum data on sleep problems that are available. From the AGRE dataset, there are data on the Children’s Sleep Habits Questionnaire (CSHQ)15 for 209 affected individuals, as well as detailed sleep data which is part of a medical history examination for 94 affected individuals, making a total of 303 affected individuals with extensive sleep data and Whole Genome Sequencing data in the MSSNG dataset. The MSSNG dataset also includes the Child Behavior Checklist (CBCL)16,17, that include questions on sleep for 810 affected individuals (independent from the individuals with data in AGRE). There are additional data that can be provided to us from the MSSNG dataset as several sites may have additional sleep data as part of their medical history assessments. In BioVU, we have also identified over 700 individuals with ASD who also have genotypic data as well as a wealth of phenotypic information on sleep and other medical comorbidities, including standardized surveys and clinical sleep histories. Taking into account that Vanderbilt University Medical Center has contributed to the MSSNG dataset, we will be careful to exclude any samples that overlap between the MSSNG and the BioVU samples.
registration_responses.q8.question: Two-group (individuals with ASD and sleep problems vs. individuals with ASD without sleep problems) case-control, cross-sectional study.
registration_responses.q12.question: Data is already collected. We will examine our questions by using data from the phenotypically and genotypically rich MSSNG dataset. We will also obtain additional phenotypic data from the AGRE dataset that maps into the genotypic data of AGRE that is included in MSSNG but has not yet been incorporated in the MSSNG dataset. A major strength of our project is that we will also incorporate analyses using the Vanderbilt University Biobank (BioVU). The BioVU sample repository consists of DNA and de-identified electronic health record (EHR) data.
registration_responses.q17.question: See information in statistical models section.
registration_responses.q19.question:
Aim (1): We will generate two separate PRS predictors (i) insomnia PRS and (ii) ASD PRS to test for associations and interaction effects within a population of individuals with ASD who have insomnia (cases) and who do not have insomnia (controls). We will use GWAS summary statistics from the largest available independent GWAS of insomnia (n=113,006) and the largest ASD sample available at the time of conducting the analysis from the Psychiatric Genetics Consortium. Co-I Dr. Davis is a member of the PGC and thus has early access to PGC data. Briefly, for our analysis, risk scores will be calculated using the recently developed Bayesian polygenic prediction method (PRS_CS) that imposes continuous shrinkage priors on SNP effect sizes. We will derive scores in the MSSNG data from the average number of risk alleles per person weighted by the effect size (log-odds ratio) at each locus. Scores will be standardized, and regression methods used to obtain estimates of a unit-increase in each outcome per 1 SD in the score. At the time of analysis, we will review if methods that account for LD and use discovery data from multiple traits are more appropriate. We will combine the questions from CBCL, dichotomize them in a ‘yes/no insomnia’ variable to determine whether the presence of insomnia is associated with the insomnia PRS. We will then add ASD PRS to the model to examine its additional contribution to insomnia. We will then harmonise the CSHQ and the medical history questions from the AGRE dataset which are extensive and detailed. We will use the best insomnia PRS predictor identified from our analysis of MSSNG and examine its association with the CSHQ sleep subscales. We will replicate the analyses in the BioVU dataset. 
Aim (2): Using PrediXcan, we will generate predicted gene expression profiles for the individuals in MSSNG, AGRE and BioVU and identify genes for which predicted expression is associated with insomnia in affected as well as unaffected individuals. Our analyses using the independent datasets of MSSNG and the AGRE, will provide us with a benchmark upon which to more extensively examine insomnia in ASD including the role of medication and response to medication (see preliminary data section).  As an additional analysis and to take advantage of the rare variant data available in MSSNG, we will use the Sequence Kernel Association Test (SKAT) to examine whether there is a greater burden of rare and disruptive variation in the melatonin and circadian CLOCK genes in individuals with ASD and insomnia than in individuals with ASD and without insomnia.

q1.value: Understanding distinctions between desire, craving, urge and temptation

q2.value: Jennifer Veilleux, Kayla Skinner, Danielle Baker, Kaitlyn Chamberlain

q3.value: 3.1.	This is an experimental study to understand distinctions between terms conveying a sense of wanting, following up a qualitative study that asked people to define desire, craving, urge and temptation.

q4.value:
Hypothesis 1: We predicted that desire and craving would be associated with higher strength of wanting than urge or temptation. Note that this prediction is inconsistent with defining craving and urge as strong desires as described in the substance use literature (Sayette, 1995) but is consistent with the qualitative data found in Study 1.  If there is a difference across goal contexts, it is likely that the higher strength associated with desire and craving will be particularly evident for long-term goals, suggesting that these two terms convey a yearning that is less evident for the impulsive urges and temptations.
Hypothesis 2: We predicted that craving and urge would be associated with higher need than either desire or temptation, particularly for short term hedonic goals.  
	Hypothesis 3: We predicted that body-related feelings would be stronger for short-term hedonic goals compared to long term goals, as these are all hedonic experiences with a physical component (eating, drinking sex).  We likewise expected to see stronger physical sensations associated with urge among the short term goals compared to the other terms, consistent with definitions provided in Study 1.
	Hypothesis 4: We predicted that temptation would differ from the other terms as being less pleasant, associated with lower likelihood of pursuing action, and being less internally driven. Finding that temptation is associated with lower pleasantness than the other three terms would replicate the within-subjects finding from Study 1. 
Hypothesis 5: Finally, we expected that the terms urge and temptation will be rated as less natural to use for long term-goals compared to desire and craving.  Urge and temptation imply momentary impulsive processes to a stronger degree than desire and craving, suggesting they may be less salient for long-term goals, but equally salient as desire and craving for short-term goals. 
	Additional prediction: Unrelated to differences in terms, we anticipated that in general people would find long term goals more internal and associated with a greater likelihood of action compared to short term goals, and that internality and likelihood of action would be correlated.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: This is a factorial between-subjects design.  Participants will be randomized to either a short-term or long term goal condition, and they will also be randomized to one of four desire terms (desire, craving, urge or temptation).  This is thus a 2 x 4 design.

q9.value: Randomization will occur via Qualtrics; participants are randomly assigned to conditon using embedded data, with the option to equally present elements.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Data will be collected via Qualtrics with recruitment via Prolific.  The only screening criteria will be living in the US; any US Prolific user will be eligible.  The study takes less than 3 minutes and peopel will be paid .45 for participation.  People will be excluded who (a) indicate they've done the study more than once, (b) report they  did not pay attention, or (c) tell us they do not want us to keep their data.

q13.value: We will recruit 800 people for this study, which is 100 people per cell (for a 2 x 4 design).

q14.value: According to GPower, a sample size of 800 gives us 95% power to detect an effect size of d = .30 or higher.

question.value:
Long Term vs Short Term condition: participants will be randomly assigned to see either three vignettes depicting long term goals (to be healthy, financially secure and in a loving romantic relationship) or three hedonic short term pleasures (eating a big dessert, sex, and drinking alcohol).

Participants are also randomly assigned to term, where they will read about this goals as either being desires, cravings, urges, or temptations.

data.name: All questions and materials for Study 2.docx

extra.selectedFileName: All questions and materials for Study 2.docx

question.value: These included (1) strength or intensity (e.g., “To what degree does Casey want to be healthy?”), (2) the sense of need (e.g., “To what degree does Taylor feel like she needs financial security”?), (3), pleasantness of the sensation (e.g., “Morgan is tempted to have sex.  How pleasant is this temptation?”), (4) the physical nature of the desire (e.g., “When Casey thinks about the urge to eat a large delicious dessert, to what degree does Casey feel it in his body?”), (5) the perceived likelihood of pursuing the desire (e.g., “How likely is Morgan to take action toward obtaining a loving romantic relationship?”), and (6) the degree of internality of the desire (e.g., “To what degree is Taylor’s urge to drink alcohol a part of herself?”).  The internality item used images of a small person and a star to represent how internal the desire is to the participant (see Figure 1; Funkhouser & Veilleux, 2019).  We finally ask how natural or normal it is to use each term for each of the goals in the the vignette.  Most of the items are on a 6-point Likert-type scale from 1 (not at all) to 6 (extremely).  The internality item is on a 7-point scale from 0 to 6.

Because each participant will see three vignettes, we hope to average across the three vignettes within each goal condition . Before doing so, we will check the internal consistency of each variable within each goal condition to ensure this is reasonable.

Models will be 2  x 4 ANOVAs on each of the seven outcome variables.  

Contrasts are planned for each variable based on the specific predictions; these contrasts will be the same for the main effect of term type as well as for an interactions involving term type.

For Strength, the central planned contrast is comparing desire and craving versus temptation and urge.  This will be followed by by examining desire vs craving and urge vs temptation.

For need, the central contrast will be comapring craving and urge vs desire and temptation, and the other two planned contrasts are craving vs urge and desire vs temptation.

For pleasantness, action, and internality, the central contrast will be temptation against the other three terms, along with desire vs craving and urge and then craving vs urge.

For body, we will compare urge against the other three terms, along with comparing temptation vs desire and craving and then desire vs craving.

For naturalness of the term, we will compare craving and desire vs urge and temptation, then craving vs desire and urge vs temptation.

q21.value: We will use the traditional p < .05 for significance, using two-tailed tests.

q22.value: We will exclude people who report having completed the study before, if they did not pay attention or if they want us to exclude their data.

q23.value: People need to have at least 2/3 vignettes completed to be able to be included in the analysis for that variable.

q24.value: Exploratory analyses will include post-hoc tests using Bonferroni corrections.
